Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of Novel Nonlinear Optical Contrast for High-Resolution Morphological and Chemical Imaging of Historical Artwork
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) program in the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI), Professors Martin Fischer, Warren Warren, Robert Opila, Dr. Jennifer Mass and their groups will develop multi-wavelength nonlinear optical microscopy techniques for the extraction of novel molecular contrast at microscopic resolution from highly scattering materials ranging from biological tissue to historical artwork. This team has recently extended microscopy methods originally developed for skin imaging to historical pigments, demonstrating non-destructive, high-resolution structural and chemical contrast in historic painting cross sections and an intact painting. This interdisciplinary study between museum conservators and academic researchers will focus on making this a broadly useful method for imaging both biomedical tissue and historic works of art: the study will broaden the range of accessible contrasts and documented pigments, demonstrate high quality imaging with maximum flexibility, and build a portable device. This work integrates seemingly disparate fields (molecular imaging, analytical chemistry, laser spectroscopy, fundamental nonlinear optics, and biomedical engineering) to address fundamental questions impacting medical imaging and cultural heritage. In the studies of artworks the use of nonlinear optical microscopy has been hindered by the lack of useful image contrast in highly complex layers of paint (most of which do not fluoresce). Pulse shaping and pulse train shaping technology, recently developed for biomedical imaging, now provides access to weaker but more pigment-specific structural and molecular contrast, which could help determine authenticity, provenance, technology of manufacture, and state of preservation.

This program could dramatically impact biomedical imaging and conservation science by providing a non-invasive imaging modality that can extract comprehensive structural and chemical information from these highly scattering environments, complementing established mapping techniques. Students involved will have access to the laser labs at Duke University, the NC Museum of Art Conservation Center and the Winterthur facilities; in turn NCMA and Winterthur staff will actively participate in the imaging studies. This exchange will encourage interdisciplinary inquiry between scientists, conservators, curators, and educators. The program will result in training opportunities in an interdisciplinary environment spanning conservation science, art history, physics, chemistry and engineering for graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological tissue and historical paintings have many similarities when it comes to optical properties - both are highly structured arrangements of absorbing and scattering components, in which the microscopic structure greatly affects their function (appearance in the case of artwork). This similarity offered a great opportunity for cross-fertilization between the fields of biomedical imaging and cultural heritage science: During the grant period, we have adapted molecular imaging techniques, which we had originally developed for imaging biological sample, for use on artworks. With this technique, we were able to extract information on several historically relevant pigments in historical paintings and in manuscripts. We chemically identified these pigments, mapped their three-dimensional distribution, and visualized their microscopic structure, without removing any part from or otherwise damaging the artwork. Such information about pigment distribution, structure, and chemistry, can help conservators and conservation scientists with attribution, authentication and conservation. In turn, we have utilized a transient absorption spectroscopy setup (developed during the grant period to identify art pigments) to study photophysical properties of melanin, a major pigment in skin and key diagnostic marker for melanoma. Using these nonlinear optical signatures of melanin, we were able to correlate melanin’s optical properties with melanoma’s metastatic potential. Benefiting both application areas, we have advanced the underlying imaging technology, pump-probe microscopy, from a proof-of-principle device to a methodology easily transferrable to other labs. For example, we have developed flexible and rapid detection methods based on low-cost field-programmable gate arrays, implemented adaptive optics methods for enhanced depth penetration, and combined pump-probe contrast with a range of other contrast types into a multimodal microscope.

The major highlight we achieved related to this project was the demonstration of nondestructive three-dimensional pump-probe imaging of several pigments in a 14th century historic artwork (The Crucifixion by Puccio Capanna). The resulting publication in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) has received the most widespread attention and has been the subject of numerous news features (a selection of which are: "3D Imaging Reveals How Paintings Were Made" in Science; "Laser Looks Under the Surface of Art" in Nature; "Pinpointing Pigments in 3-D" in Chemistry & Engineering News; "Art Under a New Wavelength" on UNC-TV; "Nonlinear microscopy of historic art" in Physics Today; and "Uncovering Art" in NSF Science 360). Furthermore, we have presented at local education and outreach events, e.g. at Duke's Open House Exploring Light Technologies, at local high schools, or a podcast at the American Scientist, just to name a few.

All graduate students involved with this project worked closely with the paintings conservators at the North Carolina Museum of Art. They also collaborated with the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, working with several conservation scientists. All graduate students have attended the Gordon Research Conference on Scientific Methods in Cultural Heritage Research and have presented their work at the associated Gordon Research Seminar. Two of the students have been elected to chair the recent Gordon Research Seminar of this topic. Furthermore, one of the students received a National Research Council Research Associateship Program Fellowship for 2015-2017, which supported her art-related research project at NIST.
